abstract.p: Margaret McGirr reply to Oct 26 letters on Oct 23 article holds kindergarten children may well enjoy cheerfully presented academic activities

block.p: In reading the Oct. 26 letters responding to ''No Time for Napping in Today's Kindergarten'' (front page, Oct. 23), I was struck by the ''either-or'' nature of the complaints about the rigors of kindergarten. Apparently, either a 5-year-old enjoys his morning making clay figurines, or he is tormented by stress over so-called academic challenges.

In reading the Oct. 26 letters responding to ''No Time for Napping in Today's Kindergarten'' (front page, Oct. 23), I was struck by the ''either-or'' nature of the complaints about the rigors of kindergarten. Apparently, either a 5-year-old enjoys his morning making clay figurines, or he is tormented by stress over so-called academic challenges.

Isn't it also possible that a child may well be delighted to take part in simple, cheerfully presented academic activities like writing a journal and reciting poetry? Small children do not distinguish between work and play. Adults are the ones who tell them that work is necessarily a misery.
